CommentText: You said: one of the best education systems in the world, well in reading the comments I'm not so sure. Do you really think that, in making Sweden more liberal, the situation would improve? Do you really think that Syrians/Turks etc. are intrinsically bad people? I know friends who visited Syria before the war and they were impressed by the people. The problem is that you took a lot of immigration (too much) without integrating them and it is the same problem all over Europe. Without a proper integration system, the people remain ignorant and then they grow attached to things like religion. Not only that: with high unemployment, the people are then more prone to enter criminal organizations. Guys, it is common sense, nothing more. I was a kid when my family migrated from Yugoslavia to Italy, my father learned Italian and found a job quickly because of a guy who was a humanitarian that helped him and many others. Right now I'm almost in my 40s and I have a university degree, a good job (my brother the same) and my family's criminal record is none whatsoever, and that's because my family was quickly integrated. And we know many Yugoslav Muslim families with the same situation, not criminals but taxpayers, even owners of companies. Right now I cannot see a quick solution to the Sweden situation but since it is nearly impossible to deport all the migrants, mostly because the countries of origin will not accept them, you have to find a smart way to integrate them. Or you can be inhuman and militarize the country, I don't know. Making the state more liberal will just create more gap between the rich and the poor and create an even worse situation. Good luck

For example, if a Syrian immigrant is closed to values and rules of Denmark, it says something about this particular Syrian refugee, however the racism, discrimination, hate or violence of some Danes are also affecting the status of the hard/good working/integrated Syrian refugees. So sometimes, it's not an immigrant problem, but more a problem that is made by the local population (sometimes based on emotional background, such as misinformation and xenophobia) or based on facts, such as real events that happened (like violence or attacks from refugees). But also in my opinion, the local people should first blame their own government, in the end they are the ones letting them in. Just don't let them in and there will be no problem. On the other hand, Europe is promoting democracy, human rights and freedom of speech, however it looks like this doesn't always apply to Middle Eastern refugees and this is actually the source of xenophobia, not seeing them as other human beings. I agree with all parts that every immigrant must integrate in the European society, but I don't think they have to assimilate, they don't have to lose their own identity in order to participate. If that is the case, then the most basic human rights like freedom of religion are taken away. I am not an immigrant, but I have a second background. I see myself as a Dutch, but also as a Turkish person. I am proud of both my nationalities. Coming back to the point, I think if they want to solve the refugee crisis, this should come from both sides. Danes should be less generalizing (not every Syrian refugee is a problem, there are hardworking, highly educated Syrians as well) and in the same way Middle Eastern immigrants must respect the Danish law and integrate in Danish society or they can go back to their own country. I am a strong promoter of integration, but I am against cultural assimilation (it doesn't work).   The hard reality is, during the time of Gadaffi, the country was more advanced, after the invasion it became worser, same with Saddam and Mohamed Morsi. I don't want to go in details, but these people were dangerous for the existence of Israel and the agenda of elites. Many of these coups and invasions are organized by geopolitical reasons, not neccesarily because these countries were killing it's own people or even attacking Europe or NATO or America. Yes they were dictators, but we have seen that the American invasion (or intervention / special military operation) resulted in war crimes as well, leaked by ex CIA Julian Assange which exposes many of the American war crimes in the Middle East. Sadly the genocide against Muslims in Bosnia (Srebrenica) was never prevented, the Dutch army back than was responsible for this prevention, it's still a black page in Dutch history and reminded every year. NATO has it's own geopolitical agenda as well, never underestimate the intentions of military organizations, once they get the power they can turn in monsters themselves. NATO is responsible for many war crimes, like every other country or group that is going to war. Like I said, I don't neccesarily see good guys in war, both parties have their own agenda. About the Russian army, it is true that their military suffered from many modernization programs (lack of resources), however in the end Russia is a nuclear power and that is a game changer and the best argument of not playing dangerous games with Russia. Any country can defend themselves, the question is for how long? Also Russia doesn't want to exterminate Ukraine, they want to replace the current government with a pro Russian regime, so it's likely that Ukraine will lose land (geopolitical shift to isolate direct NATO invasion through Ukraine). You can watch Caspian Report or Real Life Lore (which has a video about the Russian invasion, explained from both sides) if you want to know more about military analysis. The question is not who triggered this war, but rather why it was triggered? This is one of the best videos you can find on the entire internet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=If61baWF4GE&ab_channel=RealLifeLore  I can't go in details on every statement/argument of yours, but I have read them all and I understand your point of view. I just want to advice you (like in my earlier comment) war does not neccesarily have a good and a bad guy, sometimes they are both the bad guys and I am specific talking about the regimes only, not the country, not the population, but two regimes that fight each other because of disagreement. Both Ukraine regime and Russian regime have made mistakes and they were not able to solve this in a peaceful way. Two outplayed and angry regimes that had to fight each other, just my opinion, but if you watch the link I send you, it will be better to understand what I mean.   My last point of the discussion I really appreciate your open minded view, I have learned alot of new things from your replies. Most agnostic or atheist people I have had a discussion with were so obsessed with attacking Islam and are very closed to different opinions, you are exactly the opposite. I wish you a nice day and hopefully I may have changed one of your opinions or perspectives on a certain topic, so that you reconsider your thoughts about for example immigrants, Islam, Muslims or anything else we talked about. Also I want to point out that my messages include many opinion based statements, not neccesarily based on facts, if I am wrong at something, anyone can correct me.

CommentText: I'm going to give my perspective as an immigrant, I'm Chilean and I live in Brazil, I came here as a child for the first time in 1970. I'm also going to give my impression of what's happening in Chile right now. There are bad and good people in every group, and this is a truth that must always be considered! Immigrants have a tendency to seek out and have contact with others of the same nationality, maintaining a cultural bond, but... the immigrant must incorporate himself into the country that welcomed him, understand and accept the local culture, and not want to impose his or her culture (otherwise it is better to return to your country or look for a country with a similar culture). Immigrants should not have the right to vote or be political candidates... I don't consider it right, as there is no guarantee that an immigrant will not try to apply laws that favor their beliefs or their country of origin. Immigrants who do not respect local laws must be deported...! Why do I say all this? Precisely because there are good immigrants who want to work, to be useful to the country that welcomes them, and there are bad immigrants who are criminals or just going to enjoy the advantages that the country offers. I'm not saying that you can't help people, including immigrants, but you have to analyze whether you're really an honest person going through a bad time, or whether you're just someone who tries to take advantage of good citizens. Chile is currently going through a similar situation, with a large population of immigrants (many irregular) who consume State resources and do not contribute to anything... In the north of Chile, prisons contain more than 50% of immigrants, and in Chile, prisoners are not forced to work... The vast majority of land invaders, who demand their own homes, are immigrants... The Chilean State offers everything, but many immigrants believe it is their right to demand and gain all possible benefits, including houses. The big problem is that a society needs people who contribute, and who add behaviors and resources for the well-being of everyone. ParentCommentText: How Sweden is Destroyed by the Immigration Crisis
CommentText: I‚Äôm a second generation, and my wife a first generation immigrant. I speak Swedish fluently and my wife needed 6 years to learn Swedish almost fluently and on it get herself a master degree in mathematics.  We‚Äôre both civil engineers, work and gladly pay taxes. So yes there are immigrants that do well. I see us as an example of it.  However there are two major things we‚Äôve noticed along the way. One, that it has reached a point where too often all immigrants are treated equally, just for being inmigrants. And you have to really work even harder than Swedes to earn some kind of respectable treatment. Two, that relatively many immigrants are unfortunately abusing the system. Me and my wife noticed it first hand. Some, and they are not few, become very comfortable getting payed not doing much for Sweden. It hurts saying it and frustrated me a lot, but it is important to recognize the problems if you want to solve them.  Sweden needs to heavily restrict its immigration policy and demand more from people coming here. But should also encourage people who really work hard and/or are highly educated to be succesful.  Sweden is regardless of its problems a great country with amazing people.

CommentText: Did you reply to the wrong comment? Or are you just jumping the gun a little bit?  I didn't intend on even touching that topic with my comments. But since we're here I don't mind Muslims coming in, but devout Muslims are a different matter. Devout Muslims will always stick to their religion. Their religion is very anti Semitic, anti-women, anti-gay and very bigoted.  A large portion of migrants into western countries are Muslim, but will happily adopt western culture to an acceptable degree.  I'll quite happily allow them into our country as long as they can pass through legally. But Devout Muslims are a definite no.  That's my personal opinion on it. Of course there's no solid way to identify whether someone is a devout Muslim or someone who's willing to change. So this is just my personal opinion and not really something I'm saying we can or should implement. It's something with too many problems to be practical.     My original point is that these lessons aren't very effective.  The rude lady on this video said that many Muslim men would pretend to conform just for these lessons, but as soon as they're done with the lessons, they'll inevitably go back to their own ways. That is an exceptionally valid point. And then there's also the fact that the repercussions for not taking these lessons are very small.  Many people who enter our borders still don't truly understand the level of equality we have in our countries. They enter our countries as they have and begin to drag society down.  This is something I really don't appreciate about border policies and it's why I think we need stricter ones. But more specific to these lessons, they need harsher reprmimands to those who do not attend the lessons.  I live in the UK, England. We actually have parts of the country with Muslim communities. People call them "No-go zones", but you can enter them so it's not a very fitting name.  These no-go zones have 0 British culture in them. If you enter that zone with anything that the Islamic faith is against, you're guaranteed to get death threats and only about 60% of people there actually understand English.  This is the consequence of not properly teaching people how we behave in our countries. They don't respect us and our way of doing things and it means that the country changes.   This is why I think these lessons are a great idea, but they need to be implemented more firmly rather than having them look like a load of college students that don't really care about their lesson.

ParentCommentText: As an immigrant working and living in Norway, I must say that Sweden surprised me with how easily they granted work permits, permanent residency, and citizenship. In Norway, obtaining a work visa is limited to EU citizens or skilled workers. To secure permanent residency, one needs to undergo a language test and a "Samfunnskunnskap" (social studies) test. Citizenship requires passing a B1 oral language proficiency exam. I have a friend working in Sweden who holds Swedish citizenship, although his Swedish language proficiency is comparable to Tarzan's.

ParentCommentText: Can The U.S. Economy Survive Without Immigration?
CommentText:
I respect the anti-immigration argument, although I see these folks missing a big point. There are 2 categories of work guest workers do-
1. the jobs for which it's hard to find American workers  APPLYING for them
2. the jobs for which it's hard to find American workers QUALIFIED for them

The anti-immigration argument always talks about #1 to justify that in times of slow growth like now, Americans would be willing to work in those jobs too. i totally agree with it. But a blanket ban affects #2 which is completely overlooked. You cannot find American employees to replace jobs that are utilized by the H1B professionals. 
If these visa programs have been historically abused, the solution is to fix the visa policies, not vilify these H1b professionals and falsely claim that their jobs also can be done by Americans.

CommentText:
Read the book ‚ÄúA Nation of Immigrants‚Äù by John F. Kennedy. Still relevant after all these years. 

Our country cannot sustain itself long without a robust and logical lawful system of immigration, especially for workers. 

The Jessica Vaughn woman is the policy director for Center for Immigration Studies (CIS), a group that publicly advocates for much lower levels of immigration to the US. Some call them an immigration ‚Äúrestrictionist‚Äù group. 

Her views are biased and one-sided and intended to push for lower immigration levels. She cites no study or report as support for her views n this video. 

Did you see that on July 30, 2020, the GDP shrank by 32.9% in the 2Q? One reason is that worker immigrants are not doing or taking jobs because they can‚Äôt get in here. 

As the video said, they pay billions in taxes and generate demand for goods and services, thus create demand for American jobs themselves. 

Shutting down lawful worker immigration to ‚Äúsave‚Äù jobs for Americans is like shooting yourself in the foot to prove you‚Äôre a good gun marksman. 

You get a medal for supposedly hitting the bullseye but it hurts a bit and gets bloody messy.

ParentCommentText: Can The U.S. Economy Survive Without Immigration?
CommentText: First, I think the comment that immigrants undercut American wages is either completely false or statistically insignificant. For an American company to hire a skilled immigrant, for example under the H or L immigrant visa class, there‚Äôs an application process to be completed with the US govt. There‚Äôs legal fees, application fees and other associated costs like relocation. To top it off, there‚Äôs a min. yearly salary requirement based on the job level and the region. This starts in the range of $70k & up. Which brings us to the question: Why would any employer in the US do this to pay ‚Äúlow wages‚Äù. It‚Äôs mathematically impossible! Secondly, let‚Äôs talk about immigrant contributions to America, starting with this platform we‚Äôre on, YouTube. Founded by 3 people, 2 immigrants, 1 American. YouTube was acquired by Google, which was cofounded by an immigrant. Elon Musk is known for 4 companies that have been wildly successful. Elon is a South African immigrant. Steve Jobs‚Äô dad was a Syrian immigrant. Jeff Bezos‚Äô dad was a Cuban immigrant. These are just but a few examples from the recent past. There are too many examples to get into. America is a great country with a great people. Let‚Äôs not minimize the contributions immigrants have made in getting the US to where it is today. Lastly, let‚Äôs especially not play into play into the political narrative.

ParentCommentText: Can The U.S. Economy Survive Without Immigration?
CommentText:
Comming from a potential international student... I don't think people would like to change the US for China. If we can all agree on something, is that China is way more nationalistic (for obvious reasons) and xenophobic than anyone in the US. The thing that made the United States so good for inmigrants is not just oportunity, but culture; the United States makes you feel part of it, just look at top universities with former Soviet scientists turning into teachers, they can tell you about that. And well for the main factor... if China had the inmigration rate the US has (which is the highest in the world), China would do the same or worse to protect the chinese. Think about this, the US has a ~167 million people in the labor force, China has over 800 million! If the skilled workers from other nations went to China to take their jobs, wouldn't the chinese be upset? They were taught to be nationalistic af, if it isn't chinese it is inferior to them (when it comes to stealing intellectual property is another story until they change the tech a little on their soil). And even tho, in the US there are ~15 million chinese (both workers and students combined).

China doesn't want foreign-born workers, they want to RETAIN their talent. They have a population similar to all of the Americas and Europe combined, so they would have the capabilitie of living from a domestic labor force. But the problem with that is other nations, being more efficent when it comes to entrepeneurship and overall freedom. The United States, Switzerland, Singapore, the UK, Sweden, Australia, Luxembourg, Denmark, Finland, Norway, the Netherlands, Irland and Canada, are the nations with the most foreign talent in the overall ranking and some of them are way more competitive, business friendly, open and less corrupt than the chinese market. They have a demand for skilled labor so it works for the chinese that want a drastic change in their way of life.

Old chinese people might not be able to see through China's "Iron Curtain", but young people (Gen Z or late Millenials) know how to use a VPN that plays to the "cat and mouse" with the CCP censorship. They know about us and our policies, news as they are and how we interpret them in the West. That, plus how hard the chinese university entrance exam is (the Gaokao), makes the US's SAT/ACT an excellent oportunity for a skilled teenager/young adult to obtain a full ride scholarship at a Need-Blind or non-need-blind for internationals rich university. Or with the growing middle class in China, it makes it a great oportunity to aim for a public research university like Purdue, or Berkeley, or in more obvious terms the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaing, which holds over 5,000 chinese students out of its 30,000+ students. 

So... having that in mind, me being an prospective international student from Colombia, if I had to change a United States higher education and potential entrepreneurship oportunities... I would have to study my undergrad here to apply for the Fullbright for a Master's Degree, because even tho the US has expensive education, it has the best scholarships; If I was granted a scholarship at Cambridge, or Oxford, I would still have to pay like US$31k there, and the average colombian makes US$14.7k a year. 

So let's say I go for work, let's say I made my Bachelor in Science, Master in Science and my Ph.D in Colombia (which I don't want to). Changing the US for another nation... I would go to... I dunno. I like a country that can offer me a bit of everything; strong economy, strong education, strong military, strong international relations, that kind of stuff... 

Which would you pick? I'm thinking about... maybe Canada? France? Germany? I dunno... I like the United States a lot, and I'm worried for it. This elections have me nervious... I dunno what would be the best for the US right now.

ParentCommentText: Those are satellites around the 4:00 mark and that is how they typically move. This is because a satellite's "light"  is reflected sunlight.  The sun is still illuminating them because their elevation is much higher than us on the ground. They can only be seen during that short window where you can be in darkness on the night side of the Earth, but the satellite can be high enough in orbit to still be in full sunlight. You won't see a satellite late at night. You will only see them for a few hours after sunset and a few hours before sunrise.

ParentCommentText:
As a student in communist Poland, I traveled to Sweden for summer work to pick strawberries for several years. My aunt also lived there. I remember Sweden as a happy country of helpful people and beautiful nature. I was interested in this country and I had the impression that for many decades the Swedish authorities, especially those from the social democratic party, have been performing a kind of social engineering towards their nation in order to transform it into some kind of utopian society.
 I have a similar impression now in connection with the mass influx of immigrants to Sweden. It has such a horrendous scale that I find it hard to believe that the authorities that allowed it to happen are not aware of the consequences it will entail. So I am convinced that this is a continuation of this experiment in which Swedish society is to become some new kind of society, some mixture of many races and cultures, whether the Swedish people themselves want it or not.

Matt, I live in Plymouth in SW UK last night police fought off a rioters in the city centre. There was a legitimate anti- illegal immigration protest and a legitimate anti-racism counter protest. Unfortunately both sides were hijacked by bad actors. I.e. genocidal slogans and Palestinian flags from the left and rent-a-mob troublemakers on the right. 3 hours in, 2-3 medium sized groups of Asians turned up and joined the anti racism protest and taunting the other side. In short, good faith protest and debate was lost in that moment and devolved into clashes against police with people's businesses damaged and looted.

Our new prime minister is not helping at all with the rhetoric, calling it "far right thuggery" and Plymouth's Council Leader just called it "right wing protest"
CommentText: I did see a couple of post were police cars that were smashed were actually delivered to the location were it "appeared" the smashing was orchestrated. ParentCommentText: Fox Host To Trump: I Do Declare, Don't Take My Au Pair!
CommentText:
An Au Pair is a younger adult (usually in their 20s) that goes to another country to learn the language and culture in exchange for raising and caring for the families children and getting a place to live whole there.  They do not get a salary.   A Nany gets paid regularly wages and maybe lives with the family maybe doesnt, and has citizenship or a work Visa in the country they are working in.  The au pairs do not. (They are similar to foreign exchange students as far as citizenship is concerned) 
Babysitters are temporary and usually are hourly and only work for special events not on a regular routine and do not actually raise the kids in any way but just watch them while parents are out at that particular event. 

That is the difference between these terms.

So basically she is NOT PAYING for her child care..... which makes this even better..... she is using this poor person to raise her kids and is supposed to be teaching him/her our culture.   Sooo sorry for them that she is the one teaching them..... because she has such an odd view of American ideals
